Description: Egyptian terracotta model sword. A model of a sheathed sword with a moulding at each end of the handle and a triple-balled pommel, decorated with impressed circles; the guard is also adorned with balls, one on each side, with a single moulding below, with faint transverse decoration. The scabbard has a single moulding at its top and a central rib. The back is plain except for a jog defining the scabbard. Apparently solid, from two-piece mould. Orange-brown Nile silt with a reddish core and abundant fine gold mica and white inclusions (<1.5mm).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), Site 95 (Petrie), the terracotta workshop, at the eastern edge of the town
Curator's comments: Locally made at Site 95 terracotta workshop noted in 1885 at the eastern edge of the city. BM1886,0401.1444, 1886,0401.1451-2, 1886,0401.1537-40, 1886,0401.1574 and 1888,0601.108 were found together at a terracottas workshop (Petrie 1886: 45). Petrie dates this workshop to about the end of the 1st century AD, Bailey 3rd to 2nd century BC. Parallels of sword-model of a different type, possibly not sheathed, with a central rib from Middle Egypt, were dated late Hellenistic period (Besques 1992: no. D/E 4546). Parallel found in the Fayum, now in Cairo Museum (TR6/3/36/1=SR5/1134). 'Site 95' written on the object in pencil. Site 95 is the terracotta workshop, found by sebakhin in 1885, at the eastern edge of the city. Besques, S. 1992. ‘Catalogue raisonné des figurines et reliefs en terre-cuite grecs, étrusques et romains, 4, 2. Epoques hellénistique et romaine. Cyrénaïque, Egypte ptolémaïque et romaine, Afrique du Nord et Proche-Orient’. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C630)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DF.05) (Phase 1)
